creator: jfparis@groupe-casino.fr
text:
Hi

The ftp task is unable to get or to list the files on a server. I suppose it'e
due to the langage settings on the serveur (it seams to be in french)

ps : I'm using commons-net 1.2.2 (downloaded todday) and my ant copy has also
been downloaded today

Oups I forget :
the ftp serveur is the one bundled with SunOS 5.8

Best regards
creator: jfparis@groupe-casino.fr
scohen@apache.org
text:
This is very interesting to me.  I've done a lot of the work on the ftp parsing
in jakarta-commons-net, which is at the root of ant's ftp task, as you probably
know.

I have never been happy about the way we handle dates.  I know that different
servers in different countries handle the dates differently.

We've never fixed it because, frankly, I've never been able to get any solid
info from developers on non-English systems to find out how prevalent the
problem is, and what is the best way to solve it.  Hopefully, you'll be willing
to share some information with me to help me understand the depth of the problem
and how we might solve it.

In your experience, in France, do ftp systems use French names for months
always, usually, sometimes, or rarely?  Are English month names ever, or
frequently seen?  Do you know much about the situation in other European
countries?  Do German servers use German names for months?  Etc.

The core of the problem is being able to tell, from an FTP server that the
client knows nothing about, what language to expect the months in.  FTP was not
originally designed as an automatable protocol and fixing this will not be easy.

But I am always eager to find people willing to help solve it from the countries
affected.

In my optinion installing a french|greman|deutch version of a ftp server is a
stupid ans silly thing. Nevertheless, i'm not sys admin everywhere and some
french versions are installed. So my answer to your question is "sometimes".

I think it is hard to guess with language you should parse. A list of all the
nonth names in all langage may be a solution to detect the language setting of the 
server. Not a very efficient way but still a way.

But maybe to handle such case, the ant task may had an option which allow a user
to transfert files ignoring any time check for dectecting newer versions.
creator: jfparis@groupe-casino.fr

text: This should now be fixed with the latest (1.4.0) release of Commons-Net.
creator: rwinston@eircom.net

text:
Ant support has not yet been released, but a vote is in progress to include the 
support for the new commons-net functionalities in the next release.  If it
passes, then this will be fixed in Ant.
creator: scohen@apache.org

text: I'll simply assume it has been fixed by more recent versions of Ant and/or commons-net.  Please re-open if I'm wrong.
creator: bodewig@apache.org
